title: Acute Diverticulitis
diagnosis_topic: Inflammation of colonic diverticula causing abdominal pain
setup_script: A 55-year-old woman with a history of diverticulosis presents with left lower quadrant abdominal pain and fever. She notes constipation and nausea.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.2 C.
Left lower quadrant tenderness with mild guarding; no rebound or peritonitis.
WBC 14 K/uL, CRP elevated; urinalysis normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT abdomen/pelvis with oral and IV contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Sigmoid diverticula with pericolonic fat stranding and small 2 cm abscess (Hinchey Ia).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and initiates IV antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Ceftriaxone plus metronidazole or monotherapy with piperacillin-tazobactam started.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient is stable and abscess <4 cm
dynamic_flow.reply: Treat with IV antibiotics alone; if >4 cm, percutaneous drainage by interventional radiology.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident manages severe or diffuse peritonitis
dynamic_flow.reply: Emergent surgery with Hartmann's procedure or primary anastomosis with diverting stoma based on stability.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident advances diet after clinical improvement
dynamic_flow.reply: Transition to clear liquids then low-residue diet; eventually high-fiber diet.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans colonoscopy 6 weeks after recovery
dynamic_flow.reply: Exclude underlying malignancy and assess extent of disease.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses elective sigmoid colectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider after two episodes of uncomplicated diverticulitis or one complicated episode in young or immunocompromised patients.
Avoiding nuts and seeds is not evidence-based; encourage fiber instead.
Warning signs requiring immediate attention and lifestyle modifications such as weight loss and smoking cessation.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of diverticulitis using CT imaging and laboratory tests
Initial medical management with bowel rest and antibiotics
Indications for percutaneous drainage versus emergent surgery
Role of colonoscopy and elective surgery after recovery
Patient education on diet, lifestyle and warning signs
